It's a solid pixel art animation software
I've tried out a couple animation softwares before coming to aseprite, and this is the first animation software i actually felt competent in using 

Though there are a few things here and there that trip me up in work flow from my time doing art in paint dot net, but it's still a lovely software

I would recommend having a secondary software alongside asesprite though, it doesn't handle larger image imports very well 
So if you want to color pick from a reference (unless that reference is pixel art which is unlikely), import that reference into another software (I use paint dot net), eye drop what you want, then copy+paste that color code into your aseprite color palette 

Also this software does occasionally go on sale, if you want to save about $6 bucks i recommend whitelisting and waiting for a sale
It is still worth the full price though, but saving money is always nice

144903995.review:
There's a trend among graphic design apps where everything must be as shortcut-heavy and as cluttered as possible. Making it so users have to study shortcuts and app mechanics before even trying to use it. On top of that, interfaces can be daunting, confusing, and sometimes counter-intuitive.

It's safe to say that Aseprite is nothing like that.

Aseprite is really simple for people who are just starting to understand pixel art. But the application also is very versatile for more experienced artists. As you gain experience with Aseprite, you can figure out more options to streamline your experience. But the things that the shortcuts and pop-up menus access are still accessible via simple buttons and tool options in the same window, making it so artists don't have to study shortcuts to only forget them two days later.

The overall layout of Aseprite is planned out well. The ability to split projects and objects between windows inside of the application itself is very useful for more complicated projects. 

I personally have no need for the open source part of Aseprite. But for those who do, it's a useful addition 
I'm sure.

There are plenty other useful tools in Aseprite on top of this. It would be too much to write everything.

The only real con of Aseprite is the frame speed when animating. It's limited to the hundredths decimal place, making it so more intricate animations (such as art syncing with music) need to be completed outside of Aseprite.

Overall, really cool tool both for beginners and seasoned veterans. I recommend it.

142843619.review:
Great software for Pixel Art animations, especially for single strip spritesheets. If you're sticking to pixel art, it is WAY better than heavier software (e.g. Krita, GIMP).
Though it does lack some small pixel art features from other free editors, but nothing vital really (e.g. shade/light from Piskel, vectorized copy-paste from GMS editor), it compensates with other great features with ease of use, such as layering, and very easy and intuitive multi-frame manipulation.
What makes Aseprite even more awesome is that you can download an official outdated version for free if you can compile it yourself, then you can try the software for as much as you want before buying it in order to have the most up to date version.
It is great nevertheless, my favorite pixel art software for the time being, and I just can't stress enough the fact that an older version can be officially acquired for free and the outdated features are more than enough for you to make a good full commercial game.

Tip: don't buy into AI plugins that propose to automate your animating process, you'll have generic animations and waste more time fixing the AI aberrations rather than if you actually just learn how to animate them manually. If you don't fix AI aberrations, you'll have some fucked up blurs once you mix it with shaders and stuff inside your game, not to talk about art style consistency too. Dat's jus' me tho'.
Edit: oh yeah, also worth noting that AI tools always bring the danger of having your game removed from certain platforms due to Copyright Infringement issues. Been there, done that.

Wonderful, and powerful, little program.
Very lightweight especially on your system.

If you're used to other Art Programs, like SAI and
Clip Studio, you'll feel right at home with the 
customizability of your hotkeys and the system settings.

It doesn't have tweening (right now), but handles animation just fine.
Frames will either automatically copy when you make new frames,
or you can make empty frames. Copy/Paste works perfectly fine in all aspects,
just as you would expect. DEL deletes the selected item, be it colours in your palette,
frames, pixels, or anything, so be careful to make sure you select what and which you want to delete.

Aside from the art tools, there's tons of additional, sprite and tile based
utilities, like tiling, skewing, colour replacements, etc.
So it's also perfect as helpful software for game development.

I recommend checking some youtube videos for pixel artwork,
not just for asesprite, as those will help you get comfortable with the medium.

The program itself is VERY easy to learn, especially if you have previous experience,
as mentioned above. And it allows you to do anything pixelart related that you would want it to.

142292626.review:
In the vibrant realm of pixel art, one tool reigns supreme, an embodiment of the saying "good things come in small packages." That tool, dear reader, is none other than Aseprite.

Pixel art, much like a well-composed symphony, is a harmonious blend of individual elements, each integral to the whole. And Aseprite, in this case, serves as the maestro, orchestrating a suite of powerful, yet intuitive tools that empower artists to create pixel masterpieces.

The Aseprite interface is as sleek and clean as a freshly wiped canvas, offering easy access to its array of features without overwhelming the user. Color selection, brush options, layer control – all available at a simple click, making the process of creation as smooth as a painter's brushstroke.

And oh, the animation tools! Crafting a lively pixel sprite that dances, jumps, or explodes in a burst of color is a breeze with Aseprite. Its intuitive timeline and onion skinning capabilities make it easy to animate your creations, giving them life and movement in a series of frames, akin to the magic of old-school animation.

But perhaps the true beauty of Aseprite lies in its attentiveness to the needs of pixel artists. Want to create a custom color palette for your retro-style game? Aseprite's got you covered. Need to apply a complex shading to your sprite? A few clicks, and it's done. With Aseprite, the focus isn’t merely on providing tools; it’s about creating an environment where the imagination can take flight, unhindered by technical constraints.

Despite its power and versatility, Aseprite remains refreshingly accessible. Its welcoming community and abundant online tutorials make it easy for beginners to venture into the world of pixel art, while its depth and adaptability continue to satisfy the creative appetites of seasoned professionals.

In conclusion, Aseprite stands as a testament to the joy of creation. It takes the simple, humble pixel and elevates it to the status of art. It's more than a tool, it's a companion for every pixel artist, a testament to the adage that in the realm of creativity, the only limit truly is your imagination.

To put it simply, this is [b]the[/b] best tool to make pixel art, sprites, and animation! There simply is no alternative that comes close to it, and it's absolutely worth the Price!
As a starting Game Dev, and avid Modder of 2D games, I find myself opening Aseprite almost everyday!

It uses a smart system comprised of both Layers and Frames to make animating as smooth as possible, and it has a bunch of tools to make spriting and animating easy and quick.
It's also very easy to get into, so that you can quickly create whatever you want, even without learning much of the intricacies of Aseprite.

To be clear though, there are some oddities you might find, causing some issues, but most of them are very rare...

This Software also is specifically designed for Pixel Art, and might not be the best tool for image editing in general.
This does not mean it's worse, just that it isn't designed for it, and if Pixel Art isn't your main focus, this might not be the best tool for you!

[h1]Overall, I give Aseprite a 9.5/10[/h1]
It is the best Tool for Pixel Art, and if that's what you are after, you will find nothing better!

139631305.review:
First of all, let me start by saying that Aseprite is an absolutely phenomenal program. From the moment I discovered it, I was blown away by its capabilities. The fact that it is open source and allows you to build it yourself is truly remarkable. However, I decided to purchase it on Steam because I wanted the convenience of automatic updates without having to manually rebuild the open source files whenever there is an update.

Now, let's talk about the user interface (UI). The UI in Aseprite is a masterpiece in itself. It has a pixelated aesthetic that perfectly suits the world of pixel art. Right from the start, you get a sense of nostalgia and artistic inspiration. It's like stepping into a time machine and reliving the golden age of gaming.

One of the things I love most about Aseprite is how incredibly simple it is to place pixels. Just pick a color and place it anywhere you like. There are no additional buttons or confusing configurations to worry about. It's pure creativity at your fingertips. And when it comes to animation, Aseprite shines brightly. The animation tools are so user-friendly and intuitive. You can easily apply tags to certain frames, labeling them to avoid any confusion. The onion skins are not overly complicated, and you can customize them to match your preferred style.

But let me tell you about my absolute favorite feature of Aseprite—the color mixer. It's a game-changer. If you're not satisfied with a particular color in your project, just open up the color mixer and make a few adjustments. It's like having a magic wand that can fix any color-related issue in an instant. The level of control it gives you over your artwork is simply astounding.

And here's where Aseprite truly stands out from the crowd—the ability to use and install community-made plugins. This opens up a whole new world of possibilities. You can apply different UI themes to customize your workspace and make it truly your own. Plus, the ability to export your projects to .psd (Photoshop File) format is a game-changer for those who work with multiple software applications. It seamlessly integrates into your creative workflow.

Lastly, I must mention the exceptional file recovery feature of Aseprite. It's a lifesaver when unexpected technical issues arise. You can rest easy knowing that your hard work is protected, and you won't lose everything in the face of a computer crash or power outage.

In conclusion, Aseprite has been an absolute joy to use. There are still a few features I haven't explored yet, but based on my experience so far, I can confidently say that this review encapsulates the countless hours of positivity I've experienced with this app. Whether you're a professional pixel artist or just starting out, Aseprite is a must-have tool that will elevate your art to new heights.

138996569.review:
First review ever, coming from an amateur of spriting and not some sort of expert.

I think this was a nice improvement from Piskel (you might still want to check that out, though! Some seem to find it good enough), since it allows for larger spritesheet importing and its animation tool is a decent upgrade from Piskel's (in which frames have pretty big icons and you have to do some scrolling to get there).

Aseprite also offers a list of preset palettes and allows you to easily create your own - I personally have added a few from Lospec and also essentially extracted others from some Kirby's Dreamland 2 sprites. Again, Piskel also has a palette manager, but it's a bit rudimentary and I am not sure if you can save them, although I am pretty sure you can in the downloadable version.

A few noteworthy features I can think of right now are an outline effect that can be applied automatically and which settings can be edited and a tileset mode which has potential, but as nothing more than an amateur I haven't done much with besides messing around with it. Some features may require you to enable the Beta version.

I think Aseprite has a friendlier interface than Piskel, but the latter still let's you more easily know what the framerate of your animation is. Aseprite is better for importing files and editing their content (which helps for modding) since Piskel will limit you and send you an error if the imported sprite is too big.

Finally, Aseprite is also more consistent with it's default checker pattern, a case will always be 16x16 in your canvas (I am not sure if those can be edited, but I feel like 16x16 it's perfect), while Piskel's background checker pattern changes if you zoom in or out.

If you feel like Aseprite is missing functions, you can use a few add-ons, I'll list a couple here as examples.

Center Image Add-on: https://thkaspar.itch.io/center-image

Sprytile (add-on for Blender compatibility allowing to create stylized textures for low-poly 3D models): https://jeiel.itch.io/sprytile

That's all, I hope this review from a pixel art enthusiast was helpful in your decision making, be sure to check out Piskel first though, in case it is good enough for you. Otherwise, you might just want to wait a little until a sale.

Amazing. It has all the tools and QOL you could ever need for pixel art and animation.

Some quick tips for aspiring pixel artists that have made a world of difference for me:
* Make sure to turn on "Pixel-Perfect" for your Brush tool
* Hold [V] and click and drag on a pixel to quickly move to the layer containing that pixel. No need to go through your layers trying to hunt it down.
* [Shift + O] is the amazing outline tool you always dreamed of.
* "Symmetry Options" is hiding under the View tab [Alt + V].
* Learning shortcuts is pretty much essential in the long run if you make sprite sheets or animations, so I recommend trying to familiarize yourself with them as soon as you start, so you can start building that muscle memory now!

137200665.review:
This isn't a full no.  Aseprite works perfectly fine for pixel art and it provides all the tools you need for palettes, animations, and seamless tiling.
Aseprite fails to get my recommendation due to its horrible UI.  The UI is clunky, everything has wide margins, and all it does is get in your face - it puts form before function and I hate that.  I like programs to be spartan and compact so I can focus on what I am doing.  There are means to reduce the amount of UI on the screen however this does not solve the problem (after all, I want to have quick access my tools, the layers, and the palette).  Changing the UI and Screen Scale only somewhat fixes this issue and the results I've ended up with still aren't ideal (everything is very small although I prefer that to the default clunkiness).  

More UI customization would be an immense improvement because there is certainly a lot of good within Aseprite hidden behind a very annoying UI.

That all said, here are some of changes I did to cope:
-Preferences > Experimental > Enable "Use native file dialog"
-Change the hard to read pixel font: https://community.aseprite.org/t/how-to-change-ui-font/5023/6

One of the most complete pixel art tools out there. 
It has a lot of features, very comfy color palette options/features, GREAT animation tools (onion skin is truly helpful), great tagging system and ease of managing layers.

As far as I know, it only has one weakness: it does not have a good tool for tilesets, but you can still make them yourself.

135841934.review: Before I bought Aseprite, I was going using a lot of free pixel art softwares and websites, like pixilart.com and lospec.com. Most of the free ones that I used were perfectly fine, but Aseprite had a lot more tools, options, and appeal to it. The UI of Aseprite is incredible. With everything from the buttons to the text font to the folders in the Open menu, everything has been pixelated to fit with the whole retro environment that Aseprite is trying to create for everyone who uses it. One of my favorite things that I discovered recently was that the Aseprite icon on the home screen blushes when you hover over it and can be pressed as a button. It doesn’t do anything, but I still thought it was adorable. 20 dollars may seem like a lot of money to pay for something you could get a lesser equivalent of for free, but Aseprite was completely worth the money. It has so much more in store for any pixel artist than any free application will. Since a lot of other pixel artists that you may see online or in YouTube tutorials use Aseprite, it’s extremely helpful to have access to the same set-up as the professionals. The tools and layout of Aseprite is the best part about it. The hotkeys for the tools are easy to learn, and knowing those hotkeys can make your art-making process much more efficient. If you don’t want to have to memorize the hotkeys, the images make it clear what each button does. Some have functions specific to Aseprite that may be confusing to first-time pixel artists, but once you understand the functions, those buttons can begin to play a major part in your workflow. I’ll probably never switch to another pixel art editor ever.

The workspace is highly customizable, allowing you to arrange the tools and panels in a way that best suits your needs. This makes it easy to switch between tasks and keep your focus on the important aspects of your work.

One of the standout features of Aseprite is its powerful layering system. With support for multiple layers, you can easily create complex designs that would otherwise be difficult to achieve. The ability to isolate individual layers, add masks, and control the opacity of each layer gives you complete control over your artwork.

Another impressive aspect of Aseprite is its animation tools. Whether you're creating simple animations for a game or more complex animations for a film or video, Aseprite has you covered. Its intuitive timeline and frame management tools make it easy to create smooth, fluid animations, and the ability to export your animations as sprite sheets or GIFs makes it easy to integrate them into your projects.

One of the things that sets Aseprite apart from other pixel-art software is its support for a wide range of file formats. Whether you're working with traditional pixel art, sprite sheets, or even animated GIFs, Aseprite has the tools you need to import, edit, and export your work with ease. This makes it an ideal solution for artists who work across multiple platforms and want to ensure their work is accessible to a wider audience.

In addition to its impressive feature set, Aseprite also boasts a vibrant community of artists and developers who are constantly creating new tools and resources to help you get the most out of the software. Whether you're looking for inspiration, advice, or help with a specific task, there's always someone available to assist you.

Overall, Aseprite is a truly remarkable piece of software that stands head and shoulders above the competition. Its professional-grade features and user-friendly interface make it an ideal solution for artists of all skill levels, and its commitment to innovation and growth ensures that it will continue to evolve and improve over time. If you're looking for a powerful and versatile pixel-art software, Aseprite is an excellent choice.
